command: bash -lc 'ufw --force enable && ufw default deny incoming && ufw logging high && iptables -I ufw-before-input 1 -p icmp --icmp-type echo-request -m length --length 123:123 -m recent --name PINGK --set && iptables -I ufw-before-input 1 -p tcp --dport 22 -m recent --rcheck --seconds 15 --name PINGK -j ACCEPT'
explanation: Uses an ICMP Echo Request (ping) with an unusual exact packet length (123 bytes) as a stealthy signal to temporarily allow SSH from the sender. This aligns with Traffic Signaling by encoding a trigger in the packet characteristics. Detection: Alert on ICMP echo-requests with uncommon lengths and correlate with follow-on SSH from the same source.
rationale_steps: Enable ufw, default deny, and high logging.
Mark sources that send echo-request packets with exact length 123 using recent:PINGK.
Allow new TCP/22 only when recent:PINGK is present within 15 seconds.
Detect by flagging atypical ICMP sizes and immediate SSH attempts in ufw logs.
